Dr. Schneier
Gives Interview
On Viet Policy

Politics Affect
Foreign Pclicy
In Vietnam

The ensuing weeks offer the
students of Hopkins a great opportunity to sample four experts'
Opinions of the grave issues of
current foreign policy. It is hoped
that the presentation of Senators Fullbright and Morse, McGeorge Bundy and Henry Cabot
Lodge will aid each member of
the Hopkins Community in forming opinions of his own.

although we have no exact figures on this—we are picking up
ten or fifteen converts to Communism in South East Asia. Thts
may be a funny twist on the
"domino theory", but it is a twist
we have invented.
Asian Withdrawal
Question: If the "domino theory" is correct, and if we withdraw from Vietnam, what do you
think would be the result?

It is in this interest that the
News-Letter publishes the opinions of Dr. Ned Schneier, an assistant professor of Political
Science at Johns Hopkins.
The following interview was
conducted in the office of Dr.
Schneier on March the first,
by Henry Korn.
Question: Senator Morse will
Speak at Hopkins this week.
What do you think of Sen.
Morse's position on Vietnam and
how does his opinion effect domestic politics?
Answer: Senator Morse has
always been a political maverick
and there is no doubt that he is
continuing to play this role in
his criticism of Administration
Policy in Vietnam. But at the
same time, Wayne Morse is one
of the most knowledgable men
in the realm of international affairs in the United States. He
Was a respected professor of international law before he turned
to the Senate, and he has been
on The Senate Foreign Relations
Committee throughout most of
his career. Thus he is someone
Whose opinions are worth hearing, he deserves a wider audience
than the American press has
thus far accorded him. I hope
that everyone will at least give
his opinions the respect they deserve, while at the same time
realizing that he certainly doesn't speak for the Administration.
Johnson Manadate
Question: Does not Johnson's
election mandate give him license to follow whatever Vietnamese policy he deems necessary? Is he responding to internal political pressure, if so from
whom?
Answer: No, I wouldn't think
of it in that way. I feel that there
is certainly a large group of what
Walter Lippman refers to as
"war hawks" in Washington, and
these people have a substantial
following in the general population. But I think too that most
of the people who are followers
of the "war hawks" are included
in that 27 million votes that went
to Barry Goldwater rather than
the 40 million that went to Lyndon Johnson.
I think that Johnson's mandate in the field of foreign affairs was based on his statements
that "Jaw-Jaw-Jaw is better
than war-war-war", or his oft
repeated remarks on the subject
of "peace-peace-peace." I think
it would be difficult to interpret
his election as a mandate for
What he is doing now.

FULBRIGHT
The Honorable J. William Fulbright (D. Ark.), chairman of the
Senate Foreign Relations Committee will deliver the George
Huntington Williams Memorial
Lecture today at 5:00 P.M. in
Shriver Hall.
Previous Williams lecturers include U Thant, Anemin Bevan,
James A. Van Allen, Jan Masaryk, George F. Kerman, and
Julian Huxley.
The lectureship was endowed
in 1917 by Dr. Williams' family.
Dr. Williams was Professor of
Inorganic Geology and the University's first Professor of Petrography. Funds from the leadership are used to secure "lecturers

Band Concert
The - sixty-one - piece Johns
Hopkins University Concert
Band will present its annual
Spring Concert tomorrow night
at 8:30 p.m. in Shriver
Director Conrad Gebelein will
conduct the band's third and
final effort of the year.
The featured piece will be the
"Suite from the Royal Fireworks
Music" by Handel. "Blackeyed Susan," a composition by
conductor Gebelein, and "On
the Trail," a selection from the
"Grand Canyon Suite" by Fende

Grofe will also be presented.
In the future, the band plants
to present a concert at a West
Baltimore church, The band will
also play at the dedication of
the new athletic center and at
the alumni parade at Homecoming.

We Have Just Begun To Write
In accession to editorship and editorialists, we bring
certain convictions of policy and some correspondent
iMenlions, a structure for action. We also bring a righteous enthusiasm, but hope at the same time to remain
aware of the pretension inevitably associated with zeal.
We remain, in any case, the judge of our own situation,
relatively uncompromising before several conceptions.
We establish a particular view of the campus: that
the campus is isolated with respect to the external political and social community; that we have by attending a
campus, acquired a shelter of toleration which allows
us to criticize anti not he silenced, to adopt and reject
any custom of behavior, even if yet unprecedented, at
will without fearing social or political retribution. Our
morality aptitude may be measured, but not our morals;
our political salience may be misdirected, but we need
not account for it.
Under these conditions, while there are no sanctions,
we may as well experiment with inventions and inquiry;
we would rather run the risk of decapitation rather than
pass up the chance to stick our necks out. That is not
to say responsibility will be totally ambivalent; we will
he responsible to common decency among other common regulations, but if, in some rare instance, our adherence to propriety appears tenuous, we welcome your
offense.
Policy dictates some intentions, and it is consistent with this that we will present when feasible, detailed accounts of news stories that assess a greater understanding of campus activity. The interview with Dr.
Schneier in this week's News-Letter is the first of such
articles.
Though this initial effort is evidently opinionated,
future stories may stick to detailed objective reports;
all articles will adhere to a common purpose: to elicit
interest or reaction. Such coverage will necessitate the
expansion of the size of the paper and a renewed awareness of extensive student and faculty concerns.
With the advent of a new and freer reign, more
Mudent particpation has already taken place and there
are expectations of more; the increase in staff will in
course, be complemented by increased student representation in the paper.
The featurizing anti abstraction of news, the use
of feature anti interview to assess campus to cosmological events will in course exceed the bounds of journalistic regulations. We have plans of presenting the
voice of the literati as well as the that of the political
hawkers from time to time, independent of the Friday
issue.
The tortoise, when pitted against the hare, veered
neither to the right or left, while the hare, making all
kinds of tale, jumping fences, lost the race; not only
did he lose, but found his way much given to thorns
and brambles. But in his enthusiasm, he covered more
ground than the tortoise could trudge through in a
lifetime.

Poetry

Poet Robert Creeley Involved
With Man And Forms He Takes
By DAVID FRANKS
This past Wednesday, through
the cohering efforts ocf Professors Coleman and Macksey of
The Writing Seminars and Professor J. Hillis Miller of the Department of English, Robert
Creeley gave a reading from For
Love: Poems 1950-1960, which
collects his previous seven books
of verse; and also read the fifth
chapter of The Island, which is
Mr. Creeley's first novel. Charles
Scribner's Sons has published
both of these books and has also
re-collected his short stories,
The Gold Diggers, which is to
be issued this fall. Mr. Creeley
has been awarded a Guggenheim
fellowship for this year, and is
presently on leave from the University of New Mexico where he
is poet-in-residence.
At this point, I must, hopefully, intrude upon this cold
listing. A formal or impartial
context is foreign to me where
Robert Creeley's work is the concern. I mean, it is certainly
relevant to know of his association with Black Mountain College, and the Black Mountain
Review which he edited there
in the early fifties. His coherences with William Carlos Williams, Charles Olsen, Robert
Duncan, etc. are relevant equally. This type of discussion however, leads one to an endless
mentioning (e.g., E.P., divers
press(s), poets, verses, re-verses,
etc., and addenda). The point is
that all of the poets that could
be mentioned in relation to
Creeley are, as he is, too important to be left here with a
dropped name.
There is a temptation in me
to quote as much of Creeley as
I can possibly manage in the
small space given to me. This is
by no means an attempt to beg

To the Editor:
Y.
"I disagree with what you
but I will defend to the death
Your right to say it." (Voltaire).
We the undersigned, representing various political views, were
deeply disturbed to note in last,
Friday's News-Letter that the
Student Council did not see fit
to investigate an alleged disregard for one student's political
freedom by a fellow student.
The recent attempts by students at Berkeley, in California,
and St. John's, in New York, to
gain the political freedom which
We now possess should force us
to realize both the extent of our
freedom, and its concomitant
responsibility.
The right of students to organize, sponsor speakers, CT protests, etc., is available to groups
of a wide political spectrum. It is
the obligation of all students, and
the Student Council as the representative of the student body.
Particularly, to insure that this
freedom is not denied any individual or group by any other
individual or group.
Political action is reduced to
the lowest common denominator
When attempts at political action
are stifled by opposing, or disinterested, people. Such actions
as tearing or burning signs from
walls, blocking prospective offcampus demonstrations, or, as alleged in this C-RAP, denying a
student's right to petition the
government, are all examples of
denials of inherent political
liberties.
It is our belief that the Student
Council has, and has demonstrated, the power to maintain a
high level of political behavior
on this campus, and we see no
reason why an incident of this
nature should pass without, at
least, an investigation.
Frederick Rosoff
Arthur W. Curtis III
Peter Dawidowicz

The ensuing weeks offer the
students of Hopkins a great opportunity to sample four experts'
Opinions of the grave issues of
current foreign policy. It is hoped
that the presentation of Senators Fullbright and Morse, McGeorge Bundy and Henry Cabot
Lodge will aid each member of
the Hopkins Community in forming opinions of his own.

Asian Withdrawal
Question: If the "domino theory" is correct, and if we withdraw from Vietnam, what do you
think would be the result?

It is in this interest that the
News-Letter publishes the opinions of Dr. Ned Schneier, an assistant professor of Political
Science at Johns Hopkins.
The following interview was
conducted in the office of Dr.
Schneier on March the first,
by Henry Korn.
Question: Senator Morse will
Speak at Hopkins this week.
What do you think of Sen.
Morse's position on Vietnam and
how does his opinion effect domestic politics?
Answer: Senator Morse has
always been a political maverick
and there is no doubt that he is
continuing to play this role in
his criticism of Administration
Policy in Vietnam. But at the
same time, Wayne Morse is one
of the most knowledgable men
in the realm of international affairs in the United States. He
Was a respected professor of international law before he turned
to the Senate, and he has been
on The Senate Foreign Relations
Committee throughout most of
his career. Thus he is someone
Whose opinions are worth hearing, he deserves a wider audience
than the American press has
thus far accorded him. I hope
that everyone will at least give
his opinions the respect they deserve, while at the same time
realizing that he certainly doesn't speak for the Administration.
Johnson Manadate
Question: Does not Johnson's
election mandate give him license to follow whatever Vietnamese policy he deems necessary? Is he responding to internal political pressure, if so from
whom?
Answer: No, I wouldn't think
of it in that way. I feel that there
is certainly a large group of what
Walter Lippman refers to as
"war hawks" in Washington, and
these people have a substantial
following in the general population. But I think too that most
of the people who are followers
of the "war hawks" are included
in that 27 million votes that went
to Barry Goldwater rather than
the 40 million that went to Lyndon Johnson.
I think that Johnson's mandate in the field of foreign affairs was based on his statements
that "Jaw-Jaw-Jaw is better
than war-war-war", or his oft
repeated remarks on the subject
of "peace-peace-peace." I think
it would be difficult to interpret
his election as a mandate for
What he is doing now.

We Have Just Begun To Write
In accession to editorship and editorialists, we bring
certain convictions of policy and some correspondent
iMenlions, a structure for action. We also bring a righteous enthusiasm, but hope at the same time to remain
aware of the pretension inevitably associated with zeal.
We remain, in any case, the judge of our own situation,
relatively uncompromising before several conceptions.
We establish a particular view of the campus: that
the campus is isolated with respect to the external political and social community; that we have by attending a
campus, acquired a shelter of toleration which allows
us to criticize anti not he silenced, to adopt and reject
any custom of behavior, even if yet unprecedented, at
will without fearing social or political retribution. Our
morality aptitude may be measured, but not our morals;
our political salience may be misdirected, but we need
not account for it.
Under these conditions, while there are no sanctions,
we may as well experiment with inventions and inquiry;
we would rather run the risk of decapitation rather than
pass up the chance to stick our necks out. That is not
to say responsibility will be totally ambivalent; we will
he responsible to common decency among other common regulations, but if, in some rare instance, our adherence to propriety appears tenuous, we welcome your
offense.
Policy dictates some intentions, and it is consistent with this that we will present when feasible, detailed accounts of news stories that assess a greater understanding of campus activity. The interview with Dr.
Schneier in this week's News-Letter is the first of such
articles.
Though this initial effort is evidently opinionated,
future stories may stick to detailed objective reports;
all articles will adhere to a common purpose: to elicit
interest or reaction. Such coverage will necessitate the
expansion of the size of the paper and a renewed awareness of extensive student and faculty concerns.
With the advent of a new and freer reign, more
Mudent particpation has already taken place and there
are expectations of more; the increase in staff will in
course, be complemented by increased student representation in the paper.
The featurizing anti abstraction of news, the use
of feature anti interview to assess campus to cosmological events will in course exceed the bounds of journalistic regulations. We have plans of presenting the
voice of the literati as well as the that of the political
hawkers from time to time, independent of the Friday
issue.
The tortoise, when pitted against the hare, veered
neither to the right or left, while the hare, making all
kinds of tale, jumping fences, lost the race; not only
did he lose, but found his way much given to thorns
and brambles. But in his enthusiasm, he covered more
ground than the tortoise could trudge through in a
lifetime.

(Continued from Page 5)
To the Editor:
Y.
"I disagree with what you
but I will defend to the death
Your right to say it." (Voltaire).
We the undersigned, representing various political views, were
deeply disturbed to note in last,
Friday's News-Letter that the
Student Council did not see fit
to investigate an alleged disregard for one student's political
freedom by a fellow student.
The recent attempts by students at Berkeley, in California,
and St. John's, in New York, to
gain the political freedom which
We now possess should force us
to realize both the extent of our
freedom, and its concomitant
responsibility.
The right of students to organize, sponsor speakers, CT protests, etc., is available to groups
of a wide political spectrum. It is
the obligation of all students, and
the Student Council as the representative of the student body.
Particularly, to insure that this
freedom is not denied any individual or group by any other
individual or group.
Political action is reduced to
the lowest common denominator
When attempts at political action
are stifled by opposing, or disinterested, people. Such actions
as tearing or burning signs from
walls, blocking prospective offcampus demonstrations, or, as alleged in this C-RAP, denying a
student's right to petition the
government, are all examples of
denials of inherent political
liberties.
It is our belief that the Student
Council has, and has demonstrated, the power to maintain a
high level of political behavior
on this campus, and we see no
reason why an incident of this
nature should pass without, at
least, an investigation.
Frederick Rosoff
Arthur W. Curtis III
Peter Dawidowicz
